thread.title: NBAer acquitted in NYPD struggle that broke his leg
thread.title_full: NBAer acquitted in NYPD struggle that broke his leg | New York Post

author: Rebecca Rosenberg
title: NBAer acquitted in NYPD struggle that broke his leg
text:
Atlanta Hawks player Thabo Sefolosha cried Friday after a Manhattan jury deliberated for fewer than 45 minutes and then cleared him of all charges stemming from a run-in he had with police outside the nightclub 1Oak in April.
Upon hearing the swift and favorable verdict, Sefolosha put his head in his hands and wept, then mouthed, “thank you” to the panel of three women and three men.
“I just wanted the truth come to out and justice to come out, and I knew what happened that night, and I feel like the world now knows as well,” the towering guard and forward said later to reporters.
“I want to thank my family, and I want to thank God because this was just an incredible moment to be able to clear my name.”
Outside the courthouse, Sefolosha, 31, shook several jurors’ hands and personally thanked them.
“They should never have brought this case,” alternate juror Dr. David Ackman told the player.
Sefolosha’s lawyer, Alex Spiro, said, “The system worked. He was innocent, and the jury got it right.”
Sefolosha was accused of disorderly conduct, obstruction and resisting arrest for allegedly interfering with the police investigation of the stabbing of ex-Knick Chris Copeland on April 8.
Sefolosha and then-teammate Pero Antic were partying at the trendy Manhattan club around 4 a.m. when Copeland, who was not part of their entourage, was slashed in the gut by a stranger outside.
Sefolosha at Manhattan criminal court on Oct. 8. Photo: AP 
Police told everyone to clear the block, but Sefolosha kept stopping, then called Officer JohnPaul Giancona a “midget,” the cop testified at the three-day trial before Judge Robert Mandelbaum.
Sefolosha took the stand Wednesday and insisted he complied with the officer’s order and continued walking. 
He also said he’d only hurled the “midget” insult after Giacona repeatedly told him, “Get off my block, this is my f–king block.”
The conflict escalated as Sefolosha reached Tenth Avenue and was about to climb into a livery cab when a panhandler Amos Canty, who was standing next to a cop, asked for a handout.
Sefolosha turned to hand Canty a $20 bill and suddenly four cops jumped him, he said.
Officer Richard Canter told jurors that he saw the 6’ 7” athlete lunge at his partner, who was next to Canty.
During the scuffle, cops fractured a bone in Sefolosha’s right leg, shelving him for the rest of the NBA season.
Spiro argued that the cops targeted Sefolosha because he was a black man in a “hoodie” and grossly misperceived his actions.
“We have him, Thabo, acknowledging somebody that everybody else forgets,” Spiro told jurors. “His crime was philanthropy.”
Prosecutor Francesca Bartolomey argued that Sefolosha repeatedly disobeyed cops and likely made up the story about the beggar.
“He was arrested and subsequently injured because of his own actions,” the prosecutor said. “The police tell you to disperse, you have to disperse.”
She added, “In this courtroom, there are no NBA stars, nobody is above the law, not you, not me, not Thabo Sefolosha.”
Prior to trial, prosecutors offered to dismiss the charges against Sefolosha if he completed one day of community service. But he rejected the deal, insisting on his innocence.
